keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for Trump’s Gaza ceasefire deal despite its international recognition.
Trump’s approval rating on Gaza rose slightly (from 37% to 47%) in an AP-NORC poll but remained balanced with disapproval at 49%, indicating minimal public support.
Trump’s overall approval rating reached a second-term low at 37% approving and 61% disapproving, worse than any point since 2017.
In a CNBC poll, Americans disapproved of Trump’s Gaza handling 50% to 41%, and his economy approval rating was at a 13-point deficit—his worst on economic issues.
Public disapproval of Trump’s inflation and cost-of-living policies reached 62% disapproving, with 34% approving.
Americans now expect the economy to improve in the next year at just 32%, and believe their wages will rise at only 31%.
Only 52% of employed Americans say they are not worried about job loss—lower than any point in the past three years under Biden.
Foreign policy issues are low on Americans’ priority list: only 4% in a CBS News-YouGov poll ranked international events as the most important issue.
Three-fourths of Americans believe Trump has not focused enough on reducing prices, highlighting economic concerns over foreign policy achievements.
The Gaza deal is viewed with skepticism due to its fragility and past failures, such as the Biden administration’s ceasefire that lasted only two months.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite claiming a major diplomatic victory with the Gaza ceasefire deal, President Donald Trump faces minimal public support in the United States. Polls show little improvement in his approval ratings, with strong disapproval on both the Gaza deal and his economic policies, particularly inflation and rising living costs. Americans show little interest in foreign policy, with only 4% prioritizing international events. The article concludes that the economy—especially inflation and job insecurity—remains a far more pressing concern than the Gaza deal, and that public skepticism about peace agreements is rooted in past failures, such as the short-lived Biden ceasefire.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
